title: Where did the Islamic religion originate? - Quora

response.answer_text: Muslims believe that Islam has always existed and that the Biblical prophets such as Jesus, Abraham, David, Moses, etc., were Muslims. But in reality, the religion of Islam was started by a man called “Muhammad”, in Arabia. He was from a city called Mecca, and later after he began to preach his new religion, he migrated to a city called Medina, where the religion took off. The Muslim calendar dates from that migration. Muslims believe that the angel Gabriel met with Muhammad while he was still in Mecca and dictated the Quran to him. So they believe that the Quran literally is the word of God, much more than Christians believe about their Bible (Christians usually act as if the Bible contains the word of God). In Medina, Muhammad’s political and religious influence grew and he was able to raise an army and take control of Mecca. Much of Arabia converted to his religion during his lifetime, and in a generation or two after his death, his message had been spread throughout the Middle East, Persia and parts of Africa. Mecca and Medina remain holy cities for Muslims to this day.

a) All the stories about Muhammad are mythological, like the stories about Zeus, Jesus, Adam, Moses, Krishna, etc. b) The name Muhammad first appears in 685. c) Islam was really started by Nabateans, whose capital was Petra. Later on the Muhammad mythological tradition about Muhammad was attached to the Nabatean beginnings. The Quran was produced in the 8th century in Nabatean territory (Nabateans invented the first Arabic script). See Islam: The Untold Story with Tom Holland.

Islam originated in southern Arabia in the city of Mecca, where the prophet Muhammad announced in 610 CE that he had begun receiving revelations. After two years, he began preaching and winning converts, initially among his family and friends. In fear of assassination Muhammad fled in 622 to Yathrib (Medina), where he continued to announce that he was receiving revelations that were eventually to form the Koran.
